It sounds like you're experiencing a difficult emotional situation. In Islamic tradition, "Al-Halim" might be an appropriate name of God to reflect on in this case. "Al-Halim" means "The Forbearing" or "The Patient", representing God's infinite patience and forbearance.

Your dhikr could be: "Ya Halim," which means "O Forbearing One." This repetition could help you strive for patience, understanding, and forgiveness, both for your father and for yourself.

As you perform this dhikr, it might be helpful to contemplate on the quality of forbearance in your own life. Think of how God is patient with all of His creations and how you might bring that quality into your relationship with your father and with yourself. This is a journey, so be patient and kind to yourself as you work through these feelings.

In addition to the repetition of the name "Ya Halim," there are several ways you can incorporate this dhikr into your life to remind yourself of the virtue of forbearance:

Reflection and Prayer: You can use the name "Al-Halim" during your prayers or quiet contemplation. Reflect on the meaning of this name and ask God to grant you the forbearance it signifies.

Writing: You might find it helpful to write down "Ya Halim" in places where you'll frequently see it, such as a personal journal, sticky notes on your desk, or a digital reminder on your phone. This will serve as a constant reminder to embody forbearance.
Mindfulness: Try to practice mindfulness and when you find yourself feeling angry or frustrated, remind yourself of "Ya Halim." This could help to calm your mind and refocus your emotions.

Discussion and Learning: You could also consider discussing the concept of Al-Halim with other people, such as in a study group or an online forum. This could offer new perspectives and deepen your understanding.

Service: Serving others, particularly those who are difficult to deal with, can be a practical way to cultivate forbearance. As you interact with others, keep the dhikr "Ya Halim" in mind.
Remember, the goal is not just to repeat the name, but to let it shape your thoughts, feelings, and actions towards greater patience and understanding. The more you incorporate it into your daily life, the more naturally it will come to you in difficult moments.
